ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class provided a really valuable perspective on how African societies responded to the slave trade, which deviates from the conventional focus on the Middle Passage and the Atlantic trade. Through this class I've also honed skills needed to analyse both primary and secondary historical sources.
good knowledge about Atlantic Slave Trade and slave system in Africa
Ability to comprehend and challenge secondary sources and fit primary documents into the context of the history to support or refute the established literature.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The class was very well-organized and the syllabus gave a comprehensive coverage of the subject matter as a whole. I also like how we started from generalizations and theories in the first few sessions to examining possible rebuttals, exceptions and nuances, finally ending the class with oral narratives.

This is an incredible course that provides the foundation and context necessary to understand the slave trade and its place in our world's history. The syllabus is very smartly scheduled to expose students to a new component of Africa and the Trade each week. I would say the greatest strengths of the course are the fascinating reading list and Proffesor Harms' unique and interesting perspective.
Great class overall with no real major weaknesses

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are looking for an easy interesting seminar then this is the one.

I really recommend this class if you want to deviate from the conventional focus on the Atlantic slave trade, and learn more about how African societies were actually shaped by and responded to the trade.

Yes! Professor Harms is fantastic and the course is loaded with important and unique ideas often skipped over in high school and in other history courses. Being a US history major, I was hoping to get out of this course a better idea of slavery outside of the North American context. Now, when I study in the future I will constantly benefit from what I have learned in this course. Great class!!
Yes! I learned a lot! If you take it, please do all the reading and take advantage of Professor Harms' knowledge!
I most definitely would. As a STEM major I was looking for a non-intense writing credit with interesting subject matter and this is exactly what I got
Yes, great engaging seminar with manageable workload.
